page.title: 15WIVELISCOMBE SCHOOL 1876
page.content: The school moved to its present site over 100 years ago in 1876. "We had a half day's holiday to carry up the slates.Those slates! We breathed on them to clean them and wiped them without a rag." The schoolroom was heated by a huge brick stove which was attended by the headmaster. The youngest teacher had to fill the inkwells on Monday mornings. As there were six inkwells in each desk, it took some time. School life followed the same sort of pattern over the next few years. Attendance varied according to season, being influenced still by local labour demands, fairs, sickness and weather. In the 1880's the wearing of blue ribbon in buttonholes posed something of a threat to discipline. "All obliged" (to remove them) "but one boy. I sent him home to have it done."
